2835FD7BC7A645E1A135DCB9F180EBD6.description: Examine the impact of faith-motivated service and communal endeavors on individuals and communities.

FB097F43F74240D4A03C626C4CEC81E1.description: Explain how the planned Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat might affect one's life, faith development and understanding of Catholic identity.

4D3B499DCFBE441B9B7DFBB2637822B4.description: Create, in collaboration with one's peers and teacher, a plan for participation in a Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat.

D8743E9719254CFAB3FB3779B0940A5C.description: Describe how one's experience in a Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat affects one's life and understanding of Catholic identity.

40549017801C4941BFB5F67E75F1ACAC.description: Explain the relevance of the Beatitudes for those seeking to heed the call to holiness.

6F6622C1940C445CA924072C7691008F.description: Analyze effects of the Church's holy missionary work including First Nations residential school experiences and other examples such as: World Youth Day, the establishment and maintenance of holy pilgrimage sites, the Crusades, Catholic education throughout the world, Catholic health care, Catholic social services.

67A743EEC828448DA83D3477E0D4DF61.description: Analyze and discuss how a person's faith and religious views may be impacted by religious role models who struggle with issues such as:  addictions (e.g., drugs, alcohol, gambling, pornography), crises of personal faith, sexual abuse (e.g., as victims or perpetrators).

A2F2D81005D446018B0CA739F60906D5.description: Examine impacts of sin, acknowledgment of sin, reconciliation and conversion on personal and societal relationships.

FDF221A0AF9F4597A54E9B22D5D29358.description: Collaborate to interpret what it means for the Church to be holy and what it means for people, as individuals, to be holy.

349823B030B144BE9462F5F76859E453.description: Contrast holiness with perfection using John 8:1-11.

31D849247DB649EA95EAFBE0F3CF66E6.description: Analyze the personal and societal effects of an imperfect Church institution and imperfect individuals responding to the call for holiness.

2C39C3E0E60F45AFB46A47CC97D05ED0.description: Discuss wounds to Christian unity such as: historical divisions (e.g., Church heresies such as Gnosticism, Arianism), modern divisions (e.g., the emergence of new sects, churches and cults), cultural conflicts including First Nations residential school experiences and others (e.g., misrepresentations of various Christian identities in media and popular culture, pro-life groups pitting church against society).

239DCCFD1F9247F4A098720C49913701.description: Discuss examples of Christian churches coming together, seeking to be faithful to Christ's desire that his disciples be one, through: common mission or service (e.g., the Anglican rite in communion with Catholics of North America, two or more local Christian denominations working together to feed the hungry, shelter the homeless, provide warm clothing to those need), joint witness (e.g., joint communion where appropriate, pro-life rally), common prayer (e.g., peace vigils, Week of Prayer for Christian Unity), a chance to learn from each other (e.g., The Common Witness Project).

E75EFDFBCF1C42AD91ADADF221683CD2.description: Describe the impact of influential events in modern Church history, including the Second Vatican Council on the Christian call to unity (e.g., Restoration of Unity, 1964).

71EDEDA06DE9434BB4DBC0441E714A7A.description: Contrast Catholic and Protestant teachings such as: Revelation (e.g., Martin Luther's "Bible alone", interpretation of Scripture (e.g., literalists and contextualists), the presence of Christ in the Eucharist (e.g., real or symbolic presence), the role, training, gender and marital status of the clergy, the nature of salvation by faith alone vs. the union, by grace, of faith and works, the theological or scriptural basis for varying number of sacraments.

075B5C5F279A4488A34DA9EE3D87624A.description: Investigate influences of the Protestant Reformation and Catholic counter-reformation on Christianity and inter-denominational relations.

ABD184A105E442C4A45CD74160B2D073.description: Discuss effects on Christianity of the Great Schism of 1054.

2B23F67E0ACE4224A96DC7F3FC851747.description: Examine the benefits and challenges of ecumenical dialogue.

C05E9E27C90742669E2F7A2AE59F33F5.description: Discuss and represent interpretations of 'the family as the domestic church' (e.g., St. Pope John Paul II's Apostolic Exhortation Familiaris Consortio – The Role of the Family in the Modern World).

CD4AD41662A54557A52692F837EE9AF8.description: Identify similarities among Church teachings, the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

188F684A0D744D759FC18D5A71C3062E.description: Examine ways in which Christ and Christian teachings are purposefully and effectively infused in contemporary society (e.g., contemporary worship music, Catholic charitable organizations, Natural Family Planning, Christian corporate philanthropy, Christian prayer at family mealtime, Week of Prayer for Christian Unity, World Youth Day).

877B0282BA25496781292B668A916746.description: Describe effects of the suppression and rejection of Christ and Christian teachings on contemporary individuals, family and society (e.g., the rise of atheism and idolatry, moral relativity or ambiguity, family dysfunction, persecution of Christians, religious extremism, diminished joy in life).

06DDC0A6DFDB418CA85E4D45B7771328.description: Identify how positive and negative portrayals of Christ and Christian teachings affect contemporary society (e.g., portrayals in fictional writing, music, film, academic discourse, architecture, political campaigns).

9C557DA7F1D442629A7AA9C5EA9F0341.description: Discuss factors that influence cultural and personal identity (e.g., gospel values, various religious, spiritual, moral and legal views).

D1DF9AB1F22145E784284A78AD3325EF.description: Investigate effects of infusion, suppression and rejection of Christian values and teachings on society.

57AED2927F624C5DA5CB3565ED682B91.description: Explain how being a disciple of Christ involves courage to live the Gospel in ways such as: being 'counter-cultural', 'living in the world but not being of the world', building a 'culture of encounter', being a 'steward of Creation'.

B6958CF12D6E4C1AA4A75E855278AA4F.description: Describe characteristics of being a disciple of Christ and reflect upon ways of developing these attributes in one's life (e.g., joy in times of tragedy, a spirit of service during times of apathy, gentleness in times of frustration).

54D63F0F7DBB4718862802425139969A.description: Construct an argument for Mary as a model of discipleship to be valued and emulated through merits such as: faithful obedience, joy, modelling the Beatitudes (e.g., poor in spirit, meek, pure of heart).

7888DB6B3B484869B4ADAF68BA389F6E.description: Examine one's understanding of and response to a personal call to sainthood using the lives of canonized saints as models of discipleship for contemporary living.

6C468FEC256E403694937B0FB8B4E767.description: Collaborate with peers to explore and contribute ideas about the statement: Going to church does not make one a good Christian, but a good Christian will want to go to church.

A883E61D3EC649EFA33F78987A411144.description: Describe how one's identity as a disciple of Christ within the community of the church is influenced by statements in the Creed including "one, holy, catholic and apostolic" church.

EB273B4A805D41D5A310E6627365FABD.description: Examine ways the Church fosters discipleship such as: teachings and support for living out the 7 virtues (i.e., the 3 theological virtues of faith, hope and charity and the 4 cardinal virtues of prudence, justice, fortitude and temperance), liturgical seasons as guide to prayer, Mass/ Divine Liturgy, liturgy (i.e., the work of the church), service, veneration of saints and Marian devotion, Scripture study courses, retreat opportunities.

A1FF66B8FDEA45BCA10228F5B1AB42BD.description: Discuss challenges and value of living a contemporary Christian life of prayer.

0D758CF49E1E4573AA044B29C3E8CC90.description: Examine implications of the Lord's Prayer for individuals and society.

610D4F8D38FA4242A704053518582772.description: Explain the implications of choosing to live as a "disciple of Christ".

DE97B0BF04D14CF983118FC939A33F11.description: Conduct an inquiry into the impact of service on individuals and society considering how service brings: joy to an individual, hope to a community, peace and justice to a society, God's grace to humanity.

3E7F73BCD6334D439B425B1EE5AFBB02.description: Examine personal and communal challenges of corporal and spiritual works of mercy within a model of Christ-like service.

20796820FCC1491F80BB47D374644D07.description: Discuss the relationship between service and the call to 'love as Jesus loved'.

FF938F611A2042C586B1B117C58E8B7A.description: Recognize how Jesus, by his nature, teachings and actions, is at the root of Catholic social teachings (e.g., the value of solidarity stems from the Incarnation, the preferential option for the poor is reflected in the Beatitudes , the call for social justice is rooted in Jesus' ministry).

F5105A39DFC84FC9824999ACB5B73F32.description: Describe how Jesus is a model of service within Scripture.

B1E2EFCC50F741FAA240645078A14CEF.description: Explain the Catholic understanding of servant leadership including the relationship between service and power (i.e., the ability to create change).

2C108A36BAA9441DADC5880D051E8822.description: Assess the value and examine challenges of a life of service in the model of Jesus.

0D22A766B3864E40B567B92BC277B5BA.description: Discuss contributions of individuals and movements, although flawed, that served as leaders in the field of labour such as: Dorothy Day and the Catholic Worker Movement, Fr. Moses Coady and the Antigonish Movement, Iqbal Masih as a child labour victim, activist and political martyr, St. Joseph as patron saint of workers.

0F2D28908B664F82853AD151BF1DE10F.description: Discuss contributions of individuals, although flawed, who served as leaders in the field of the environment such as: David Schindler and Ronald Reagan for their respective scientific and political leadership surrounding acid rain, St. Kateri Tekakwitha as patron saint of the environment and ecology, Pope Francis for his encyclical Laudato Si'.

BF7A7E083A5C418291CDE5FCAE5ECE73.description: Investigate how issues of labour and the environment connect to: the Creation accounts of Genesis, the Beatitudes of Christ, the concept of stewardship.

984E99BBE2EA49DC91CDC2731AA5ED30.description: Assess one's opinions and actions concerning various labour and environmental issues (e.g., human trafficking, child labour, climate change).

CE4EAA61F96D46BDA7C0408D2A8BF219.description: Discuss perspectives on the private, communal or government ownership of water, land and resources from Catholic and various worldviews including those of First Nations and Métis peoples.

655A41F424DC4123A08B286B0B3F38F0.description: Contrast Catholic, relativistic and Indigenous views of justice concerning labour, the environment and globalization (e.g., legal and moral considerations).

58C1C094FC9A4DED824553C2AA5E6481.description: Investigate moral issues and consequences for individuals and society relating to: labour (e.g., foreign labourers, forced labour, child labour, humane working conditions, employment equity, dishonest accounting practices), the environment (e.g., privatization of water, sustainability issues, deforestation, resource extraction, food production practices such as use of animal growth hormones and genetic engineering).

5517156F01B44B1F99D2C07282361962.description: Examine how Catholic social teachings influence personal views regarding issues of labour and the environment.

6C4190ADCF4541FFA74A718BDA152F7C.description: Debate complexities surrounding the issue of clear personal consent including popular culture terminology (e.g., culture of sexual consent, no means no, silence is not consent, or rape culture).

85B48A41004741D2B3D0FA60AC44231A.description: Examine the relationship between sexual morality and: human dignity, free will, power dynamics.

28B86AE3CB374A71A17DE012136916D8.description: Evaluate implications of Catholic, secular and scientific views on moral issues of reproductive ethics (e.g., in-vitro fertilization, designer babies, gender selection practices and eugenics).

17825216FCC243A8B20DBAF163CCC09E.description: Evaluate implications of Catholic, secular and scientific views on issues of sexual behaviour and contraception methods (e.g., chastity, promiscuity, direct vs. indirect sterilization or contraception).

6E95776A7951422090A580EEBCD6EECA.description: Assess the ethical implications of Natural Family Planning as a form of birth control and other birth avoidance techniques (e.g., various forms of artificial contraceptives, sterility-inducing surgical procedures).

6CA629F9FE014226A1369BAD0E535158.description: Analyze key themes within Saint Pope John Paul II's Theology of the Body such as: the body expresses the person (e.g., the power and symbolism of body language in our actions including sexual acts), sex is an expression of love and a gift from God (e.g., chastity aids in understanding the positive purpose and basic 'goodness' of sex, a reflection of Christ's love relationship with the Church), the contradictory natures of love and lust, discerning the value of self and others including the call to love throughout one's life, a sacramental worldview (e.g., invisible realities, grace influencing ethics).

2B9E562071134FE1A5AC673D66D04F77.description: Analyze key themes within Blessed Pope Paul VI's encyclical Humanae Vitae such as: humanity belongs to God rather than everything belonging to humanity (e.g., my body, my life, my choices), sex as a gift from God, sex cannot be separated from its purpose (i.e., a unitive act conveying committed love with openness to life).

DCD6C375ED2E4722A4592CF554B82643.description: Contrast Catholic teachings with secular views regarding human sexual morality and reproductive ethics.

D30DDCE6FDF042A1B02A476679355876.description: Analyze how the faith and works relationship impacts the mission of the Church (e.g., an action-oriented mission).

88E151BBBA3E4985BE12BDE227C9E76E.description: Discuss challenges faced by the Church as she strives to fulfill her mission (e.g., political and social challenges).

0F3CD6FCE21543E081B4433D99366D24.description: Examine how joyful involvement in the mission of the Church is assisted by traditions and practices such as: use of the liturgical calendar (e.g., feast days, memorial days, liturgical seasons), Church pilgrimages or reverence of holy sites, seeking grace through the sacraments and everyday life, patronage of the arts throughout Church history, honouring of Canonized Saints and other Catholic holy men and women, Church youth groups.

D7D9AF05C72F498C95928C1435E2A67E.description: Contrast the communal nature of the Church with the individualism of modern society.

00CD385AA0B145E4B57B71D392F7EA57.description: Discuss how the mission of the Church is supported through the celebration of sacraments in various Catholic churches through their rites (e.g., Roman, Byzantine, Chaldean, Coptic).

A6B13493F131479EA6E41FAB90747D0E.description: Describe how evangelization is supported by models of Church proposed by Cardinal Avery Dulles including: Sacrament, Institution, Servant, Herald, Community of disciples.

B00767FD3B7346408C95A562E5413434.description: Explain how the evangelical mission of the Church is supported by the five actions identified by the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops including: Proclaiming Jesus Christ Worship Christ through the sacraments, Form a communion of people, Give witness, Serve.

52D5AED0C7EF464E9FFAFE6461938D49.description: Review the mission of the Church (CCC773) and recognize how the Church is to be a gift to the world especially in the ways of love, joy, peace and service (e.g., Jn. 15:10-12).

75AC5CE5A8054C2AB2A7D8566986D074.description: Examine the Church's mission and its actualization.

EC37995CBDC043ADBD289B6D0774E045.description: Examine liturgy and the Mass within Tradition and their role in Revelation.

59A22A54F9744D598293A63F5CFAD6FD.description: Distinguish between acts of veneration and worship from a Catholic religious perspective and show how acts of veneration (i.e., devotions) to the Virgin Mary and the saints are part of the Tradition of the Catholic Church.

1F44A4D8E9914E1390EE248E3A72433B.description: Describe the role of Peter within Tradition (e.g., the founding of the Church, Apostolic succession).

2128B07143874C9283257BCF8937E532.description: Discuss ecclesial traditions within the Church such as: meditations involving stained glass windows such as Blessed are the Pure in Heart and others at St. Augustine's Church in Wilcox, Saskatchewan., cultural music including First Nations drumming within Catholic masses, pilgrim events such as: Byzantine celebrations at the Shrine of the Venerable Nun Martyrs Olympia and Laurentia in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan events at Saint-Laurent de Grandin established by Fransaskois and Métis peoples, the annual Shrine of Our Lady of Lourdes Pilgrimage at St. Peter's Colony, Saskatchewan. sacramentals (e.g., blessings) as distinct from sacraments.

F3128F8250E14B33A1932A5D41F7726F.description: Differentiate between Apostolic Tradition and ecclesial traditions within the Catholic Church.

53C14D051BD24CB89244BE45E14D1DCB.description: Discuss Tradition (i.e., Apostolic or Holy Tradition) and Scripture as the two complementary forms of Revelation (see CCC 80-83).

C1F54D73B212473486CDF7DB837196C6.description: Investigate how Tradition complements Scripture as a form of Revelation in the Catholic church.

13D2869E3CAD4ABEA03056EEB5F0C60A.description: Examine how one's personal faith impacts wellness (e.g., physical, mental, emotional, spiritual domains of the medicine wheel).

70FC7B351D1D45B8A3AF8078E3469F26.description: Investigate how the Church calls the faithful to respond in hope to people suffering from grief, end-of-life challenges, and illness (e.g., St. Pope John Paull II's Apostolic Letter On Human Suffering).

A981EDAAEF2A435AB1BC134BCB173563.description: Explain or represent personal viewpoints on how one knows that the Creator God understands his or her suffering (e.g., physical, mental, emotional, spiritual domains of the medicine wheel, the suffering of Jesus as the second person of the Trinity).

D8D5177DB38E42208CB1B323C4124D81.description: Construct personal views on the nature of suffering by comparing Catholic views of 'redemptive suffering' in light of the joy of the Gospel with: traditional First Nations and Métis beliefs, various worldviews (e.g., Viktor Frankl, Helen Keller, the Buddha).

B3DD2D89F7EB483F84D983D8EE85DF78.description: Investigate how arts expressions may challenge, clarify and develop religious and spiritual understanding of the mysteries of suffering, death and resurrection (e.g., hope-filled imagery, icons, expressions of joy, concepts of compassion).

6E66377F3D054EFA906886A4A583681C.description: Examine how Jesus' suffering, death and resurrection reveals the depth of God's love and power to bring life from death and light from darkness.

34E59144C0874F4D8429F820A53548E9.description: Conduct an inquiry into the struggles and joy of the Paschal Mystery (i.e., Jesus' suffering, death and resurrection).

135A754C5B8D4825AE2F1D4023AEC3C0.description: Examine how the Paschal Mystery, as the foundation of the Catholic faith, shapes views on suffering, death and resurrection.

5050A87B5DF044D08A306A6EAF65CBDB.description: Discuss how individuals and movements, although flawed, can impact society by demonstrating characteristics of one or more of the Beatitudes: 'poor in spirit' (eg., Saint Mother Teresa, Saint. Paisios of Mount Athos), 'those who mourn' (e.g., Lieutenant-General Roméo Dallaire, marches for missing and murdered Aboriginal women), 'the meek' (e.g., Moses, Rosa Parks, Saint Pope John XXIII), 'those who hunger and thirst for righteousness' (e.g., Blessed Oscar Romero, Wangari Maathai, Anne Cools, environmental activist groups), 'the merciful' (e.g., Irena Sendler, Nelson Mandela, Tommy Douglas, Venerable Metropolitan Andrey Sheptytsky), the pure in heart' (e.g., Mary and Joseph as the parents of Jesus, Joseph Chiwatenhwa , Mary Ellen (Bellelle) Guerin), 'peacemakers' (e.g., Betty Williams and Mairead Corrigan, Jimmy Carter, Fr. Albert Lacombe, Pîhtokahanapiwiyin/Poundmaker), 'those persecuted for the sake of righteousness' (e.g., Agnes MacPhail, Saints Felicity and Perpetua, Louis Riel).

A4166EB3DA7240F7B0941BE285F0850A.description: Represent the joys and challenges of living out the Beatitudes (e.g., role play, short story, cartoons).

5460B42FDE7948BCBDB9591EFC32EA7D.description: Explain how the Beatitudes call individuals to assume personal responsibility within society (e.g., support cultural understanding, environmental and social sustainability, and the marginalized).

8DD779619DAF4BD385E047E318554046.description: Support the concept that living the Beatitudes is a pursuit of goodness involving more than the avoidance of evil.

27819F9E92614C88AC7B02B08B1012F6.description: Differentiate the concept of joy from happiness and explain how one's joy results from living the Beatitudes.

8E28B733DE41441C9F1827545594AD96.description: Discuss understanding of the Beatitudes including: 'poor in spirit' – recognizing one's spiritual poverty and powerlessness to save oneself 'those who mourn' – acknowledging wounded relationships and the need for God's grace, the meek' – keeping one's power or strength under control; curbing selfish desires to be obedient to God's will, 'those who hunger and thirst for righteousness' – desiring to learn and do the will of God; seeking to live in right relationship, the merciful' – showing forgiveness and/or compassion in a time of need, 'the pure in heart' – setting one's mind and will to God's call abiding in faith, hope, and love,'peacemakers' – reconciling broken relationships, those persecuted for the sake of righteousness' – suffering for following the will of God, living the Beatitudes with courage.

4EDDB79557FF4540A62D1503C761F127.description: Assess how living the Beatitudes of Christ affects individuals and society.

F7A0EB3AFEF74F8E987CAB5387371684.description: Support the Christian conviction of Jesus as Lord using scriptural examples such as: teachings of Jesus (e.g., parables, Sermon on the Mount), Peter's declaration about Jesus at Caesarea Philippi, Jesus' response and subsequent renaming of Peter (i.e., Mt. 16: 13-20), The Passion, resurrection and ascension, the experience of the centurion at the foot of the cross (i.e., Mk. 15:39), Jesus being: the pre-existing Word (i.e., John1:1-5), the way, the truth, and the life (i.e., John 14: 6) the son of David, the son of Abraham (i.e., Mt.1:1) "I am" through multiple personal identity statements in the gospel of John.

2F32EC42D14F4EBABB1DCF4BF4BE00C7.description: Examine the identity of Jesus as Lord through the use of C.S. Lewis' "liar, lunatic, or Lord" apologetic argument.

E36F879B8527472B9167001118638497.description: Evaluate Church doctrine relating to Jesus as Lord of humanity through Mary, the bearer of God (i.e., Theotokos), such as: The Immaculate Conception (i.e., Mary preserved from the stain of Original Sin in St. Anne's womb), The Incarnation / The Annunciation (i.e., the Word made flesh), The Nativity – virgin birth (i.e., Jesus conceived by the power of the Holy Spirit).

280E80744F564EF79CA6A575140C5BA4.description: Evaluate Church doctrine relating to Jesus as Lord, second person of the Trinity, such as: Creator of all, pre-existent Word made flesh, divinity and humanity of Jesus (i.e., Hypostatic Union).

BD2A93A87CC4499788A1AA224A8A0C6B.description: Describe how belief in Jesus as Lord affects one's life and community (e.g., joy, hope, forgiveness, generosity).

9CD35855227A48D7B2CDE48EFF239F06.description: Examine the Christian conviction of Jesus as Lord.

7CB9CC8EC5B9416DB68071CCFB5E9027.description: Reassess one's response to Jesus' call to a personal relationship with him through the Eucharistic covenant.

2E9EEE31DE3A4D80A6F6BFA0D3FAE6CE.description: Discuss the following concept: Good works don't bring salvation, but the joy of salvation reveals itself in good works through God's grace.

4842FC8E816D474A9F223AB8B2BA4735.description: Represent the Catholic understanding of Eucharist as a source of joy and hope supporting the call to live joyfully within a covenant relationship with Christ.

19C6E838E13B424BAF9E979D6B01B57E.description: Collaborate with peers to explore compelling questions about how the Eucharistic covenant affects one's everyday life involving core concepts such as grace, salvation, forgiveness, hope, love and joy.

18B52D0E794642EAB7923813B098A300.description: Conduct an inquiry into the nature of love including its prominence within the Eucharistic covenant and examples of signs of love in society (e.g., agape/unconditional, eros/romantic, philia and philio/brotherly and sisterly, encyclical Deus Caritas Est – God is Love).

4EAD385C3E574DB38507617C38AE5C63.description: Explain how the Resurrection reveals core Catholic beliefs such as: new life after death, hope (CCC 1817-1821), Jesus as Lord, pointing to the heart of the Christian faith, the possibility of transformation throughout one's life.

3FE1DE2C96B2431FBEDFFF6B369FF1C8.description: Identify key events from the breaking of the covenant by Adam and Eve to the fulfillment of God's covenant with humanity through Jesus including Luke 22-24 and Acts 1-2.

2D2F876CE0E649B890B013CFEA32815B.description: Examine the fullness of God's covenant through Jesus and how it applies to one's life.

C1D00A2C3265446C84B4F304036ABA24.description: Exploring the Joy of a Catholic Identity
